_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management of Franzia Winery Sanger is committed to maintaining a safe work environment. Safety and Environmental Managers have been assigned to ensure safe practices are followed in the specification and operation of systems involving hazardous chemicals. This site has developed and trained its personnel to an Emergency Evacuation Plan to ensure prompt evacuations during an ammonia emergency. The Plan has specific written evacuation and reporting procedures in place to protect Franzia Winery Sanger employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release.

    Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Franzia Winery Sanger facility covered by this RMP is located at 2916 South Reed Avenue in Sanger, California. The facility produces grape juice that is fermented into wine. The facility uses sulfur dioxide for bacterial control and anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration. 
A stationary anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system is used for chilling wine. System A at the facility has nineteen chillers and a total of anhydrous ammonia less than 22,000 pounds.
The sulfur dioxide system at the facility is located in the center of the winery. Sulfur dioxide is stored in two 1-ton cylinders that supply and fill smaller hand-held sulfur dioxide cylinders ranging from 6- to 100-pound cylinders. The sulfur dioxide is injected from the smaller cylinders into the wine to control the bacteria. This system holds a maximum of 4,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide, and to date is exempt from RMP requirements.

Note: The amount of sulfur dioxide onsite (4,000 pounds) is below the threshold amount required by the federal RMP regulation. The Sanger facility has not received formal notification from the Administering Agency (AA) that pursuant to Section 25534 of HSC an RMP is required to satisfy CalARP Program requirements as they pertain to sulfur dioxide, this plan only addresses federal RM

P requirements as they pertain to ammonia.


    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention of accidental ammonia and sulfur dioxide releases at The Wine Group?s Franzia Winery Sanger Facility is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original design and construction of the ammonia refrigeration and sulfur dioxide systems (i.e. double-block scenario relief valves, ASME cylinders), the specification and review of system modifications, and the day-to-day operation and maintenance of the systems, including the following. 

?Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at initial construction and modification
?Thorough Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) at least every 5 years using accurate process safety information
?Operating Procedures reviewed by PHA
?Appropriate initial and refresher training of system operations and maintenance personnel
?Preventive and corrective maintenance 
?Established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols
?Use of qualified contractors for work on the system


    Five Year Accident History

Between June 1999 and the present, no ammonia or sulfur dioxide releases resulting in onsite or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damage, or in off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have been reported.

    Emergency Response Program

Franzia Winery Sanger has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to be adequately prepared to rapidly and appropriately respond to an ammonia release emergency as well as other site emergencies. The plan, kept at the Plant Office, describes outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release. It details evacuation procedures and response procedures for the mitigation of minor ammonia releases. Usually the Fresno County Fire Department will respond to any non-minor leaks or leaks that cannot be repaired. Employees are trained to this ERP and in the event of a non-minor leak will evacuate and take

initial life safety precautions, as described in the planning document.

    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Based on the studies conducted during preparation of this Updated RMP, the Franzia Winery Sanger facility has identified adjustments that will be implemented to ensure continued safe operations. These items where identified in a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) that was conducted December 3, 2004 and have been made a part of this plan.

    RMP Review and Update

The Franzia Winery Sanger facility will review and update this RMP at least once every 5 years as appropriate. This RMP will be updated in any of the following situations:

?No more than 3 years after a newly regulated substance is first listed by USEPA or Office of Emergency Services (OES)
?No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present in an already covered process above a threshold quantity
?No later than the date on which a new regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process
?Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised PHA or hazard review
?Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised off-site consequence analysis. The off-site consequence analysis must be updated, if any change to the process, quantity stored/handled, or any other items that might increase or decrease the distance to the endpoint by a factor of 2 or more
?Within 6 months of a change that alters the Program level applied to any covered process.


    Record of Revisions

Note: All changes to this plan will become a part of this plan and will be documented in a table with the following headings:

Revision Number;
Date of Change;
Date Entered;
Signature of Person Entering Change;
Description of Changes;
